content:
EXISTING STRUCTURES
────────────────────────
### Copper Cable Factory at (≈2.5, 17.5)
Consists of the following interconnected entities that form the interface for copper cable production:
• New factory burner inserter at Position(2.5, 16.5)
• Dedicated burner inserter (placed with direction RIGHT) at Position(3.5, 17.5)
• Cable factory input chest at Position(2.5, 17.5)
• Assembling machine at Position(1.5, 19.5)

This structure is designed to receive raw materials via transport belts (despite repeated connection errors) and feed them into the assembling machine for copper cable production.

### Belt Depot for Extraction Connection at (3.5, 15.5)
Consists of the following entities assembled to serve as an intermediary depot for belt routing:
• Wooden chest (crafted and placed as belt depot) at Position(3.5, 15.5)
• Dedicated transport belt segment placed adjacent at Position(4.5, 15.5)
• Dedicated depot burner inserter (using direction UP) at Position(3.5, 14.5) whose pickup position aligns with the depot chest

This depot is intended to gather items from the extraction system before further moving them into the copper cable factory setup.

ERROR TIPS
──────────
• Transport Belt Targeting Errors  
  – When connecting transport belts, the target must be a valid inserter. Repeated errors occurred due to attempting to connect belts directly to a Prototype.SteamEngine object. Always ensure that an inserter (which inputs items into the machine) is used as the connection target.

• Entity Placement Distance  
  – An error placing a wooden chest at (3.5, 15.5) was reported because the player’s position (0, 0) was too far (15.89 units, exceeding the maximum allowed distance of 10). Move closer to the target position before attempting placement.

• Inventory Shortage  
  – A placement error occurred when no wooden chest was found in the inventory. Verify that the required items are available in the inventory before placing an entity.

• Variable Reference Error  
  – A NameError (“name 'target_chest' is not defined”) indicates a mismatch or omission in variable naming. Ensure that variable names used in target assignments are defined consistently.
